title: Righteousness and Wickedness
shortSummary: Proverbs 28 contrasts the lives and outcomes of the righteous and the wicked, emphasizing the blessings of obedience to God's law and the consequences of sin. It highlights wisdom, integrity, and trust in the Lord as keys to a prosperous and secure life. This chapter encourages believers to live uprightly, confess sins, and rely on God rather than their own understanding.
timeline: c. 10th century BC - Period of Solomon's Proverbs compilation

keyCharacters.name: The Righteous
keyCharacters.description: Those who live according to God's law, characterized by boldness, integrity, and trust in the Lord.

keyCharacters.name: The Wicked
keyCharacters.description: Individuals who reject God's law, live in deceit and oppression, and ultimately face downfall and fear.

keyCharacters.name: The Poor
keyCharacters.description: Often mentioned as vulnerable yet capable of uprightness and wisdom, contrasting with the rich who may be conceited or perverse.

keyCharacters.name: Princes and Rulers
keyCharacters.description: Leaders whose understanding or lack thereof affects the welfare of the land and people.

definitions.definition: The practice of charging excessive or unlawful interest on loans, condemned as unjust gain.
Something detestable or loathsome to God, often referring to sinful actions or attitudes.
Showing partiality or favoritism, which is condemned as unjust and sinful.
Acknowledging one's sins openly and turning away from them, a prerequisite for receiving mercy.

outline.heading: Contrasts Between the Wicked and the Righteous
outline.description: This section contrasts the fear and instability of the wicked with the boldness and understanding of the righteous who seek the Lord, highlighting the importance of obedience to God's law.

outline.heading: Integrity Over Wealth and the Value of Wisdom
outline.description: Emphasizes that uprightness and adherence to the law are more valuable than riches, and that wisdom leads to honor and blessing, while sin leads to shame and downfall.

outline.heading: The Role of Leadership and Justice
outline.description: Describes the dangers of wicked rulers and oppressors, warning that violence and lack of understanding bring ruin, while hatred of covetousness prolongs life.

outline.heading: The Rewards of Righteous Living and the Consequences of Folly
outline.description: Encourages diligent work, faithfulness, and generosity toward the poor, while warning against haste to be rich, pride, and trusting in oneself rather than God.

application: Confess and forsake your sins regularly to receive God's mercy and avoid spiritual ruin.
Trust in the Lord rather than your own understanding to walk wisely and be delivered from folly.
Practice generosity toward the poor, knowing that God blesses those who give and curses those who ignore the needy.
Avoid partiality and favoritism in judgment, striving for fairness and integrity in all relationships.

keyVerses.text: The wicked flee when no man pursueth: but the righteous are bold as a lion.
keyVerses.significance: This verse powerfully contrasts the fearfulness of the wicked with the confidence of the righteous, illustrating the security found in living according to God's ways.

keyVerses.text: He that covereth his sins shall not prosper: but whoso confesseth and forsaketh them shall have mercy.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the necessity of repentance and confession for receiving God's mercy and experiencing true prosperity.

keyVerses.text: He that trusteth in his own heart is a fool: but whoso walketh wisely, he shall be delivered.
keyVerses.significance: Warns against self-reliance and promotes wise living through dependence on God's guidance for deliverance.

keyVerses.text: He that giveth unto the poor shall not lack: but he that hideth his eyes shall have many a curse.
keyVerses.significance: Encourages generosity and compassion, promising God's provision for those who help the needy.
